metadata.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Respondent Company

facts.text: By an Indenture of Lease dated January 12, 1944, the Ruler of Korea State granted a 30-year mining lease of 5.25 sq. miles to Sir Mukherji B. Dadabhoy for payment of rents and royalties at graded rates from 5% to 25% based on coal price per ton.
On merger of Korea State with Madhya Pradesh, the leased area became subject to Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, 1948 and Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 on October 25, 1949.
In 1952, Sir Maneckji agreed to assign the lease to respondent-company; State of Madhya Pradesh consented on November 6, 1952, requiring compliance with lease terms including royalties to State.
Mazumdar Award published May 25, 1956 increased colliery workers' wages; Government of India increased controlled coal price, raising royalty under graded lease rates for respondent-company.
Respondent-company represented to Government of India on October 5, 1956 seeking royalty modification to 5% of f.o.r. price per Mineral Concession Rules, 1949.
Mines and Minerals Regulation and Development Act, 67 of 1957 passed December 28, 1957; Amending Act 15 of 1958 passed May 15, 1958; Act brought into force June 1, 1958.

Amending Act 15/1958 inserted sec. 30A retrospectively, suspending secs. 9(1) and 16(1) for pre-1949 coal leases, empowering Central Government to apply them with exceptions/modifications by notification.

Central Government notification December 29, 1961 under sec. 30A applied sec. 9(1) to pre-1949 coal leases with modification: royalty at lease rate or 2-1/2% of f.o.r. price, whichever higher, in lieu of Second Schedule rate.
Central Government letter July 4, 1962 to respondent-company: royalty rate under consideration in consultation with State Government.
State Government order September 23, 1963 to Collector, Surguja: recover royalty at 5% from July 1, 1958 subject to minimum Rs. 2,47,000/- per year; prior periods at old lease rates.
State Government order October 1, 1965 partially suspended September 23, 1963 order, directing recovery from December 29, 1961 at lease rates per Central notification S.O. 30 dated December 29, 1961.
State Government rejected respondent-company representations on November 19, 1965.
Central Government notification January 1, 1966 directed 5% royalty for pre-1949 lessees.
State Government order February 11, 1966 instructed Collector to charge 5% from January 1, 1966.
Collector served demand notices January 25, 1966 on respondent-company for arrears from December 29, 1961 to December 31, 1965 at lease rates.
Respondent-company filed revision before Central Government under Mineral Concession Rules, 1960, pending when writ filed.
Respondent-company filed writ petition in March 1966 in Madhya Pradesh High Court quashing October 1, 1965 order, November 19, 1965 rejection, and demand notices.
Madhya Pradesh High Court judgment and orders dated December 20, 1966 in Misc. Petition Nos. 139 and 182 of 1966 allowed the writ, holding royalty at 5% from December 29, 1961.

legal_issues.text: Construction of sec. 30A of Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957 and notification dated December 29, 1961: whether pre-1949 coal lessees paying higher royalty under lease must pay lease rates or capped at 5% under Second Schedule.
Validity of State Government's order dated September 23, 1963 reducing royalty to 5% and its rescission by order dated October 1, 1965.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in construing sec. 30A and notification dated December 29, 1961; notification clearly requires payment at lease rate or 2-1/2%, whichever higher; since lease rates higher, company must pay lease rates.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sec. 30A, Mines and Minerals Act 1957; Notification S.O. 30 dated 1961-12-29

petitioner_arguments.text: State Government's order dated September 23, 1963 was erroneous and inconsistent with notification, rightly rescinded by order dated October 1, 1965; State entitled to recover at lease rates post-notification.

respondent_arguments.text: Purpose of sec. 30A suspension was not to burden pre-1949 lessees with higher royalties; notification modifications intended to cushion/reduce burden under sec. 9(1), not increase beyond 5%; lessees with higher lease rates pay 5%.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sec. 30A, Sec. 9(1), Second Schedule, Mines and Minerals Act 1957

respondent_arguments.text: State order September 23, 1963 modified lease terms (5% with minimum guarantee); State could not unilaterally rescind it.

court_reasoning.text: Sec. 30A enacted to phase in uniformity in royalties without sudden enhancement to 5% for pre-1949 lessees; suspended sec. 9(1) application, allowing Central Government to apply with modifications not exceeding 5%.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object was to avoid unsettling coal industry; Statement of Objects and Reasons and parliamentary debates confirm preventing automatic rise to 5% at one stroke.

court_reasoning.text: Notification December 29, 1961 applies sec. 9(1) (5%) subject to modification: pay lease rate or 2-1/2% whichever higher only if lower than 5%; cannot mean higher than 5% as that exceeds sec. 30A power and sec. 9(1). Prefer construction upholding validity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Literal construction urged by State would invalidate notification; State's own 1963 order understood it as 5%.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly quashed State orders and demand notices; no need to decide if 1963 order modified lease as notification construction resolves controversy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State not entitled to recover higher than 5% from December 29, 1961.

holdings.text: Respondent-company liable to pay royalty at 5% of f.o.r. price under sec. 9(1) and Second Schedule from December 29, 1961, not higher lease rates.
State Government's orders dated October 1, 1965 and demand notices quashed.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1948
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to make rules for grants, modifications of pre-1949 leases; Mineral Concession Rules, 1949 r.41 fixed 5% royalty.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Regulation and Development) Act, 1957 (Act 67 of 1957)
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulation of mines/minerals; uniform royalty at 5% for coal; sec. 30A suspended sec.9(1)/16(1) for pre-1949 coal leases, allowed application with modifications.

statutes_cited.name: Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Amendment Act, 1958 (Act 15 of 1958)
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective insertion of sec. 30A to phase royalty increases.

statutes_cited.name: Mineral Concession Rules, 1949
statutes_cited.relevance: Royalty at 5% f.o.r. price for coal, min. 8 annas/ton.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Union power over regulation of mines and minerals development.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, agreeing with Madhya Pradesh High Court that respondent-company is liable for royalty at 5% of f.o.r. price from December 29, 1961 under sec. 9(1) read with notification, not higher lease rates; quashed State orders and demand notices.
outcome.relief_granted: Writ petition upheld; no recovery at lease rates for period December 29, 1961 to December 31, 1965.

key_quotes.text: "the true construction and effect of the notification dated 29th December 1961 is that in regard to coal mining leases granted before 25th October 1949 if the rate of royalty stipulated in the lease was higher than 5% of f.o.r. price per ton, then the royalty payable... would be the one specified... namely, 5 per cent"
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: High Court's interpretation of notification adopted by Supreme Court.

key_quotes.text: "A modification, if any, would be for charging royalty at a rate lesser than the one provided under sec. 9(1) and the Second Schedule, and not at a rate higher than such rate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of modifications under sec. 30A.

key_quotes.text: "the modification could not mean recovery at a rate inconsistent with sec. 9(1) and the Second Schedule, that is, at the rate higher than 5% provided thereunder."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects State's literal construction to uphold notification validity.
